reviewText:
I loved seeing this film again. My name is Junifer Tate Smith and I worked on the making of this film in the summer of 1968. We premiered it at
Expo "69 in New York. It brought back the summer of my youth and I was able to recapture the wonder of discovery on the threshold between childhood and adulthood. Even though I was only seventeen at the time,  I was struck by the attention to detail and expertise  of J. D.'s directing and filming techniques. He knew what he wanted and took whatever steps necessary to achieve his vision, whether it was building a set or building a mechanism for shooting a scene. What J. D. accomplished with the final product was to flesh out and give substance to a previously unfinished slice of Civil War prose. Even today, I remain impressed. .

You'd have to be a fan of Gordon Baxter's writing to really enjoy this to the max. He does a nice job as an actor with a character that is mostly well directed. Additions to the original Ambrose Bierce story make it a bit overwrought in places. The extra DVD features about the remastering of the original film and critical comments are very interesting.

I enjoyed the film, but it is very dated, the music and camera work scream 1970S!!!!
The nice thing about a period piece is you can avoid a "dated" look, but the director chose to make a more contemporary film.
Too bad, the best works of art are timeless, sadly this isn't.

I'm a fan of Gordon Baxter's writings, I was disappointed we don't get to hear him much...

I had seen this when it was first shown. I wanted to watch it again because when my children were young we had canoes along Village Creek near Silsbee, Tx, where this film was actually shot. I thought it was a good movie because of the suspense and because of the ending. I thought Gordon Baxter did an excellent job in his role
I was so glad to see this offered for sale. I have been searching for this movie for years. Service for purchase was very good. Thanks

As a writer planning to adapt some Bierce stories for film, I was curious about how this one was done. Most films are products of their time, and this one screams 'dated.' The music is horrible but typical TV show over the top stuff, and the uniforms are atrocious since the '70s were not known for their authenticity to detail in anything historical!

Mainly, the story is dulled by changing Bierce's ending,(I won't spoil it) and adding a silly storyline that tries to create backstory on the main character but instead just slows everything down into too many flashbacks.

I understand Tony Scott did a version, but I cannot find a way to get a copy. It can only be a 100% improvement over this sorry effort.

Based on a little known story by Ambrose Bierce (a name Civil War fanatics will recognize) the film is interesting with a twist at the end that causes one to ponder the helplessness of man and the power of fear.

VCI Entertainment presents "One of the Missing" (1978) (Dolby digitally remastered)...Under director/producer/screenplay  J.D. Feigelson, short story by Ambrose Bierce...the cast include Gordon Baxter (sniper confederate soldier), Talmadge Armstrong (union soldier), Linda April Raines (the girl). . . . . .short story by Ambrose Bierce and adaptation by J.D. Feigelson set during America's Civil War, this film follows the grim fortunes of a scout who becomes trapped in the rubble of a bombed-out house behind enemy lines...the sniper is now in a life or death situation, we are left to decide whether we should feel for him or hope he gets his just what he deserves...it's up to the enemy combatants to determine whether the soldier lives or dies... flashbacks to the sniper's childhood will cloud your decision, which will make it hard to guess the surprise ending.....there is a great deal of entertainment for the serious "film-buff"...all courtesy of VCI Entertainment, who in my humble opinion is the best there is in restoring early serials and features like this one.

SPECIAL BONUS FEATURES:

1.  Director's Restored Version (includes extra footage)

2.  Director's Commentary

3.  Director's Documentary on the Restoration

4.  Original Theatrical Trailer

5.  Special Introduction by Actor Charles Durning

6.  Bonus Introduction and interview with J.D. Feigelson, Hosted by Ray Bradbury

7.  Closed Captioning

Great job by VCI Entertainment for releasing the "One of the Missing" (1978), digital transfere with a clean, clear and crisp print...looking forward to more of the same from the ''70s vintage...order your copy now from Amazon or VCI Entertainment, stay tuned once again with a top notch Westerns from VCI...so saddle up and get ready for some hard riding and adventure that only VCI Entertainment (King of the Serials) can deliver...just the way we like 'em!

Total Time: 54 mins on DVD ~ VCI Entertainment 8447 ~ (5/30/2006)
